value_description: percent of population eating fortified vehicle
notes: Consumption of the fortified food vehicle was found to relatively low; however, it is important to note that many households were not able to report a brand name for certain food vehicles and as a result there was a high proportion of households with unknown fortification status when attempting to link the reported brand used in the household to the laboratory analysis of food specimens collected from markets. As a result, estimates of consumption of fortified food vehicles reported here are likely underestimated and should be interpreted with caution. In Balochistan, confirmed coverage of the fortified food vehicle in this survey was 11% for salt (71% unknown), 39% for oil/ghee (54% unknown), and 5% for wheat flour (45% unknown). In Punjab, confirmed coverage of the fortified food vehicle was 36% for salt (38% unknown), 31% for oil/ghee (65% unknown), and 1% for wheat flour (25% unknown). In Sindh, confirmed coverage of the fortified food vehicle in this was survey was 34% for salt (64% unknown), 20% for oil/ghee (59% unknown), and 10% for wheat flour (40% unknown).

Based on quantitative tests of 94 samples at production level, passing samples are in line with the minimum requirement of the relevant Nigerian Industrial Standard for fortified foods.

value_description: percent of vehicle that is fortified
source_citation: Sablah M, Klopp J, Steinberg D, Touaoro Z, Laillou A, Baker S. Thriving Public—Private Partnership to Fortify Cooking Oil in the West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) to Control Vitamin A Deficiency: Faire Tache d’Huile en Afrique de l’Ouest. Food and Nutrition Bulletin. 2012;33(4_suppl3):S310-S320. doi:10.1177/15648265120334S307
notes: For vegetable oil, coverage of adequately fortified oil was not as high as expected: only 53% was adequately fortified (≥ 4 µg of retinyl palmitate per gram)

value_description: percent of vehicle that is fortified
source_citation: Sablah M, Klopp J, Steinberg D, Touaoro Z, Laillou A, Baker S. Thriving Public—Private Partnership to Fortify Cooking Oil in the West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) to Control Vitamin A Deficiency: Faire Tache d’Huile en Afrique de l’Ouest. Food and Nutrition Bulletin. 2012;33(4_suppl3):S310-S320. doi:10.1177/15648265120334S307
notes: A significant difference was observed between the North and the South of Côte d’Ivoire: 81% of samples were adequately fortified in the South and only 12% in the North. This clear difference between the North and South of the country can be explained at least partly by the geopolitical situation. Until 2007, the northern portion of the country was not under government control, and hence, borders were poorly controlled and several cheaper brands of unfortified oil from neighboring countries were found.

value_description: percent of vehicle that is fortified
source_citation: Sablah M, Klopp J, Steinberg D, Touaoro Z, Laillou A, Baker S. Thriving Public—Private Partnership to Fortify Cooking Oil in the West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) to Control Vitamin A Deficiency: Faire Tache d’Huile en Afrique de l’Ouest. Food and Nutrition Bulletin. 2012;33(4_suppl3):S310-S320. doi:10.1177/15648265120334S307
notes: A significant difference was observed between the North and the South of Côte d’Ivoire: 81% of samples were adequately fortified in the South and only 12% in the North. This clear difference between the North and South of the country can be explained at least partly by the geopolitical situation. Until 2007, the northern portion of the country was not under government control, and hence, borders were poorly controlled and several cheaper brands of unfortified oil from neighboring countries were found.

National Fortification Assessment Coverage Toolkit (FACT) Survey in Tanzania, 2015. Switzerland. 2016. Defined as the percent of households where the food vehicle used by the household is processed industrially: Â 36.6 (29.2, 44.0) [% (95% CI)].

value_description: percent of population eating fortified vehicle
notes: Population coverage of fortified food. Africa Academy of Public Health (AAPH), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition (GAIN). National Fortification Assessment Coverage Toolkit (FACT) Survey in Tanzania, 2015. Switzerland. 2016. Defined as the percent of households where the food vehicle used by the household was confirmed to be fortified by quantitative analyses, i.e. the sample provided or brand reported contained >19.6 mg/kg total iron (the estimated intrinsic iron amount):  2.5 (1.3, 3.7) [% (95% CI)].

value_description: percent of population eating vehicle
source_citation: Kismul, Hallgeir et al. “Diet and kwashiorkor: a prospective study from rural DR Congo.” PeerJ vol. 2 e350. 15 Apr. 2014, doi:10.7717/peerj.350
notes: The age group here is "preschool" the survey mentioned that the 90th quintile of the age distribution was 66.5 months = 5.5 years. This is the percentage of children who consumed MAIZE, not necessarily maize flour. The results were stratified by the outcomes 'developed kwashiorkor', 'developed marasmus', 'didn't develop kwashiorkor'. For each, means and 95% CIs were calculated. I used these to calculate the pooled 2.5% and 97.5% CIs here: https://github.com/ihmeuw/vivarium_data_analysis/blob/master/pre_processing/lsff_project/LSFF_extraction_kenya_11_19_2020.ipynb

notes: The age group here is "preschool" the survey mentioned that the 90th quintile of the age distribution was 66.5 months = 5.5 years. This is the percentage of children who consumed WHEAT, not necessarily wheat flour. For each, means and 95% CIs were calculated. I used these to calculate the pooled 2.5% and 97.5% CIs here: https://github.com/ihmeuw/vivarium_data_analysis/blob/master/pre_processing/lsff_project/LSFF_extraction_kenya_11_19_2020.ipynb

notes: Folic acid fortification in salt has been discussed as a needed preventative intervention to Ethiopia's high burden of nerual tube defects. However, this is not yet happening generally it is currently reserved to trials. Gates foundation has confirmed this in email correspondence with Jonathan Gorstein.

value_description: percent of population eating fortified vehicle
notes: Percentage of households consuming adequately iodized salt. "In the 2005 EDHS-II, households’ cooking salt was tested for iodine content. Salt that contains at least 15 ppm of iodine is considered to be adequately iodized. Results showed that only 20% of households consumed adequately iodized salt. Overall, there was no difference between urban and rural areas. Prevalence of salt iodization was low in all regions, except in Dire Dawa but the sample in that region was very small and the estimate cannot be considered as meaningful. Moreover in Addis Ababa region the percentage of households using adequately iodized salt was lower than 20% (CSA and ORC Macro, 2006)." **Note that salt idodizaton became mandatory in 2011 in Ethiopia

notes: Households were defined as one person living alone or a group of people (not necessarily related to each other) living at the same address with common housekeeping (sharing either a living room or a sitting room or at least one meal each day) [13]. To be eligible for the survey the household must have contained a caregiver with a child aged under 2 years old. source_additional: This is the proportion of people who answered some quantity > 0 to "did you consume any purchased [loose maize flour or sifted maize flour] in the past 7 days?". This is thus an upper bound for industrially produced [loose maize flour or sifted maize flour]. In the paper that lead me to this survey, they were using this proportion as a proxy for fortified [loose maize flour or sifted maize flour].
notes: nationally representative survey: proportion of people who answered 'yes' to 'did you consume rolled maize flour in the last 7 days?' or 'did you consume sifted maize flour in the last 7 days?'

The caregiver may have been the child’s biological mother or the person who cared for and gave the child most meals on most days.  Atta wheat flour

value_description: percent of population eating industrially produced vehicle
notes: "WHO and UNICEF note that the decree has not been implemented after more than two years since its adoption". Decree initiated on March 15, 2016. Vietnam needs 1.5 million tons of cooking oil each year, but domestic production can satisfy 40 percent of the demand, while the remaining must be fed by imports. Local players under Vocarimex, a state-owned holding company, control over 90% of the overall market of vegetable oils in Vietnam. Key popular brands are Tuong An and Cai Lan, which cater to both industrial and retail consumers, particularly low- and middle-income.  Using 90% as industrially produced number as stand-in for now.

source_citation: Industry data sent by BMGF done by Muhlenchemie

value_description: percent of vehicle that is industrially produced
notes: "WHO and UNICEF note that the decree has not been implemented after more than two years since its adoption" - iron and zinc mandatory in wheat flour. Assuming 100% industrially produced wheat flour as Vietnam does not produce wheat at all, all wheat is imported and there are over 30 grain mills in Vietnam that produce wheat flour - I have not seen any mention of non-industrially produced wheat flour in any news articles I've read. It is described that wheat products are largely consumed in urban areas in fast food restaurants, in homes rice is the primary staple food though wheat consumption has increased in recent years due to urbanization, increase in wages to eat out, etc.

value_description: percent of population eating industrially produced vehicle
notes: In an effort to explore the potential of new food vehicles for large-scale food fortification in West Africa, the Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition (GAIN) took advantage of two Fortification Assessment Coverage Toolkit (FACT) surveys conducted in West Africa (Burkina Faso and Nigeria) that measured quality, coverage and/or consumption of mandatorily fortified foods, for exploring the potential of other industrymanufactured foods for fortification. In Nigeria, all three foods had high coverage in a fortifiable form; in Ebonyi (100%, 95% and 83%, respectively) and to a lesser extent in Sokoto (99%, 45% and 40%, respectively)

value_description: percent of population eating industrially produced vehicle
notes: In an effort to explore the potential of new food vehicles for large-scale food fortification in West Africa, the Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition (GAIN) took advantage of two Fortification Assessment Coverage Toolkit (FACT) surveys conducted in West Africa (Burkina Faso and Nigeria) that measured quality, coverage and/or consumption of mandatorily fortified foods, for exploring the potential of other industrymanufactured foods for fortification. In Nigeria, all three foods had high coverage in a fortifiable form; in Ebonyi (100%, 95% and 83%, respectively) and to a lesser extent in Sokoto (99%, 45% and 40%, respectively)

value_description: percent of population eating industrially produced vehicle
notes: In an effort to explore the potential of new food vehicles for large-scale food fortification in West Africa, the Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition (GAIN) took advantage of two Fortification Assessment Coverage Toolkit (FACT) surveys conducted in West Africa (Burkina Faso and Nigeria) that measured quality, coverage and/or consumption of mandatorily fortified foods, for exploring the potential of other industrymanufactured foods for fortification. In Burkina Faso, the results revealed that rice, tomato paste, and bouillon cubes are widely available across all regions of the country, although over 90% of the available brands are imported. In Nigeria, all three foods had high coverage in a fortifiable form; in Ebonyi (100%, 95% and 83%, respectively) and to a lesser extent in Sokoto (99%, 45% and 40%, respectively).

In Burkina Faso, the results revealed that rice, tomato paste, and bouillon cubes are widely available across all regions of the country, although over 90% of the available brands are imported. In Nigeria, all three foods had high coverage in a fortifiable form; in Ebonyi (100%, 95% and 83%, respectively) and to a lesser extent in Sokoto (99%, 45% and 40%, respectively).

value_description: percent of population eating vehicle
source_citation: Huybregts, L. F., Roberfroid, D. A., Kolsteren, P. W., & Van Camp, J. H. (2009). Dietary behaviour, food and nutrient intake of pregnant women in a rural community in Burkina Faso. Maternal & child nutrition, 5(3), 211-222.
notes: The dietary assessment study was performed in December 2004 over a 4‐week period subsequent to the main maize harvest. All Pregnant women in the two villages were invited to participate in the survey. Locally trained home visitors sampled conveniently by self‐selection an equal number of women who were neither pregnant nor lactating from the same residential quarters of the villages as the Pregnant women. There were two exclusion criteria: the first being outside of the range of childbearing age (15–45 years) and the second being seriously ill and unable to participate in the study. The survey was undertaken in two villages, Koho and Karaba, in the health district of Houndé, province of Tuy, Burkina Faso. The small city of Houndé is located at the highway from the capital Ouagadougou to Bobo‐Dioulasso with a population of approximately 40 000 inhabitants. Koho is a widely dispersed village along this highway, at 4 km from Houndé whereas Karaba is a small, more centralized village at 6 km from Houndé. In Koho, the principal ethnic group are the Moore, who is a predominantly Muslim population. The Bwaba form the main ethnic group in Karaba and are mainly Christian. This region has only one rainy season situated between May and October. The harvesting season of the main cereal crops (maize, sorghum and millet) is situated from October to February.

This region has only one rainy season situated between May and October. The harvesting season of the main cereal crops (maize, sorghum and millet) is situated from October to February.

notes: Under 5 defined as age 12-59 months. Values are means 6 SEs unless otherwise indicated. The Large Cities, consisting of Douala and Yaoundé, two urban areas that together make up ~20% of the total population.

source_citation: Grant J Aaron, Valerie M Friesen, Svenja Jungjohann, Greg S Garrett, Lynnette M Neufeld, Mark Myatt, Coverage of Large-Scale Food Fortification of Edible Oil, Wheat Flour, and Maize Flour Varies Greatly by Vehicle and Country but Is Consistently Lower among the Most Vulnerable: Results from Coverage Surveys in 8 Countries, The Journal of Nutrition, Volume 147, Issue 5, May 2017, Pages 984S–994S, https://doi.org/10.3945/jn.116.245753
notes: These are 95% CIs, rather than 97.5! Note the study said that "A citywide representative survey was conducted in one country (Côte d'Ivoire)." It also said that this survey was conducted in all 10 communes of Abidjan (capital of Cote dIvoire), and that the survey population was caregivers with children aged 0-23 months.

source_citation: Grant J Aaron, Valerie M Friesen, Svenja Jungjohann, Greg S Garrett, Lynnette M Neufeld, Mark Myatt, Coverage of Large-Scale Food Fortification of Edible Oil, Wheat Flour, and Maize Flour Varies Greatly by Vehicle and Country but Is Consistently Lower among the Most Vulnerable: Results from Coverage Surveys in 8 Countries, The Journal of Nutrition, Volume 147, Issue 5, May 2017, Pages 984S–994S, https://doi.org/10.3945/jn.116.245759
notes: these are 95%, not 97.5% CIs! survey pop = households and women of reproductive age (18-49 y). survey response were poor (45% in eastern cape, 40.4% in gauteng). the main reasons for nonresponse in these surveys were refusal from community leaders or associatoins, inability to access gated communities, and no one being present at home at the time of the survey

notes: these are 95%, not 97.5% CIs! survey pop = households and women of reproductive age (18-49 y). survey response were poor (45% in eastern cape, 40.4% in gauteng). the main reasons for nonresponse in these surveys were refusal from community leaders or associatoins, inability to access gated communities, and no one being present at home at the time of the survey

value_description: percent of vehicle that is fortified
source_citation: Industry data sent by BMGF done by Muhlenchemie
notes: Assumed to be % of industrially processed wheat flour fortified with iron - columns J and K (note German industry company who made this spreadsheet as the source - Muhlenchemie), column H we should already have extracted from GFDx. Only gave compliance lower and upper ranges.
